III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4127 Staff to resident ratio
Section (4) When residents are asleep or otherwise outside of the direct
Description supervision of staff, staff shall perform variable interval, eye-on
checks of residents. The time between the variable interval checks
shall not exceed fifteen minutes.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
1

Allegation Agency failed to complete variable interval checks on residents
when outside of the direct supervision of staff.
Investigation Interviews
On 05/23/2025 an in-person interview was completed with Chief
Administrator (CA) and Program Manager. After reviewing the
agency supervision logs, they both confirmed that the
documentation by the staff did not follow requirements of variable
intervals. CA advised that a previous revised supervision log form
that had been created which included variable interval times had
not been utilized by the staff.
Documents Reviewed
Havenwyck Hospital Patient Observation Rounds Policy – Policy
indicates that during quiet time and sleeping hours staff shall
perform rounds in variable time increments not to exceed 15
minutes, checking on patients in a varying pattern or sequence
throughout the unit to minimize planned acting out opportunities.
Havenwyck Hospital Supervision Logs – Round Sheet review
showed multiple dates where checks were completed at
exactly15-minute intervals (12:00am, 12:15am, 12:30am, 12:45am
and 1:00am).
Analysis At the conclusion of the investigation, the agency was found to be
in non-compliance with licensing rule. Review of supervision logs
confirmed that agency failed to document variable interval checks
when youth were outside direct supervision of staff.
Conclusion Repeat Violation Established
2024SIC0001816 CAP Approved 01/22/2025
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4142 Health services; policies and procedures.
Section (1) An institution shall establish and follow written health service
Description policies and procedures addressing all of the following: (e)
Dispensing medication.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Staff failed to dispense medication as prescribed.
Investigation Interviews
On 05/23/2025 an in-person interview was completed with
Registered Nurse. She acknowledged that medication record logs
for a number of youth failed to document that prescribed
medication was dispensed. She reported that she believed the
2

medication was dispensed and the record had not been updated
to reflect it was given. She denied knowledge or the presence of
other documentation that would support that medication was
dispensed and not missed on this day.
On 05/23/2025 in-person interviews were completed with Youth A,
Youth B and Youth C. The three youth could not recall instances
where their prescribed medication was not provided.
Documents Reviewed
Havenwyck Medication Administration Policy – Policy indicates
that appropriate agency personnel will complete the following:
A. Chart the medications immediately after administration on the
Medication Administration Record (MAR).
B. Chart any medication, to include PRNs, which has been
refused or not taken on the MAR. Document refusals to include
rationale on a Medication Note in the Progress Notes section of
the patient's chart.
Tour
A tour of the medical room of the agency was completed. It was
found to be well organized, and medications were properly stored.
No other areas of concern were noted.
Analysis At the conclusion of the investigation, the agency was found to be
in non-compliance with the licensing rule. Review of medical logs
confirmed that the agency failed to dispense medication to youth
as prescribed.
Conclusion Violation Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. A corrective action plan is required.
